0: Image copyright AP Image caption Rescuers have been working in difficult conditions NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Crews recovered two more bodies on the third day of search efforts at a retirement home in Quebec that was destroyed by fire. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ten people are confirmed dead after Thursday's blaze in L'Isle Verte, north-east of Canada's Quebec City. Twenty-two are missing. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Search teams brought in new equipment - designed mainly for de-icing ships - as temperatures hovered around -10C (14F). NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Police are examining the theory the fire was started by a cigarette. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR However, spokesman Lt Guy Lapointe told a news conference on Saturday that it was one possibility among many. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The ruins of the Residence du Havre have collapsed and are frozen over with a thick layer of ice from fire hoses. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The conditions are very, very difficult," Lt Guy said on Saturday. "Our people are exhausted." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said the ice was as thick as 60cm (2ft) in places. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR About 20 elderly residents survived the fire, officials say.
